columns.text: In this task, we have to determine **what will happen to the price of the given bond if the interest rate increase by 15\% when nothing else changes.**

To determine whether the price would increase or decrease, we do not need to calculate the present value of the future payments of the bond. We need to know only how interest rates affect the price of the bond. **Higher interest rates negatively affect borrowing costs**. In this case, the borrowing cost for the borrower was lower before the increase of the interest rate. So, in our case, we have increased the borrowing costs. When nothing else is changed, **higher borrowing cost leads to higher bonds price**.

If the coupon rate changes (increased for a higher percentage than the interest rates), the price of the bond will be lower. But **the coupon rate stays the same. It is a fixed amount, so the price is going up.**
We need to determine how does the value of the bond change with increase in interest rate.

We will prove the correctness of our assertion numerically later, but first, let's try to see if we can reach a theoretical conclusion.

**Interest rate of a bond in a market** is called **bond yield** (or just simply yield).

Now, total value of the bond depends on two parameters:

1. Present value of coupons;
2. Present value of face/par value.

**Coupons** are **interest amounts paid out in regular intervals**, which is **an annuity**.

Their present value is **annuity present value**, which is defined as:

$$\text{PV}_\text{a}=\text{C} \times \frac{1-\dfrac{1}{(1+\text{r})^\text{t}}}{\text{r}}$$

where:

$\text{PV}_\text{a}$ = present value of coupons;\
$\text{r}$ = yield;\
$\text{t}$ = **periods to maturity** (ie. periods until face value payment);
$\text{C}$ = coupon value.

In numerator, with increasing $\text{r}$, the fraction decreases. However, 1-decreasing value = increasing value.

Although, increasing value divided by bigger increasing value (ie. 0.5/0.5 > 0.55/0.7 (exemplary numbers)), meaning that as a result, **coupon value decreases**.

Par value is the **base value of the bond**, which is a simple single amount, its present value will be **present value of a single cash flow**, defined as:

$$\text{PV}'=\frac{\text{F} }{(1+\text{r})^\text{t}}$$

where:

$\text{PV}'_\text{a}$ = present par value;\
$\text{r}$ = yield per period (or simply yield);\
$\text{t}$ = periods to maturity;\
$\text{F}$ = par value at maturity.

Evidently, (1+r) will increase, increasing the value of the numerator, and as a result, decreasing the total face value.

So, we have a sum of two decreasing values. Therefore, **with interest rate increase, the bond's value should drop**.

A name for bonds that pay out less than its face value is called *discount bond*.

Let's prove our assertion with numbers. If we pick the par value as $1,000 at 10 years maturity (arbitrary amounts), we will have the following:


| Parameters| Values| 
|:--:|:--:| 
|Par value |$1,000 | 
|Original yield |7% = 0.07 | 
| Periods to maturity |10 years|

Coupon value is simple interest value, therefore originally, coupon value is $\$1,000 \times0.07=\$70$.

Coupon's present value will accordingly be:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{PV}_\text{a}&=\text{C} \times \frac{1-\dfrac{1}{(1+\text{r})^\text{t}}}{\text{r}}\\[15pt]
&=\$70 \times \frac{1-\dfrac{1}{(1+0.07)^{10}}}{0.07}\\[15pt]
&\approx \$492
\end{aligned}$$

Bond's par present value will be:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{PV}'&=\frac{\text{F} }{(1+\text{r})^\text{t}}\\[15pt]
&=\frac{\$1000}{(1+0.07)^{10}}\\[15pt]
&= \$508
\end{aligned}$$

Total bond value is therefore $492+  $508 = $1,000, which is as we expected, considering we were working with base values for all parameters.

Now let's redo all calculations with increased rate after 1 year. ie. 9 year of maturity:


| Parameters| Values| 
|:--:|:--:| 
|Par value |$1,000 | 
|Increased yield |15% = 0.07 | 
| Periods to maturity |9 years|

Coupon value **remains the same**, but only yield changes.

Coupon's present value will accordingly be:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{PV}_\text{a}&=\text{C} \times \frac{1-\dfrac{1}{(1+\text{r})^\text{t}}}{\text{r}}\\[15pt]
&=\$80 \times \frac{1-\dfrac{1}{(1+0.15)^{9}}}{0.15}\\[15pt]
&= \$334
\end{aligned}$$

Bond's par present value will be:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{PV}'&=\frac{\text{F} }{(1+\text{r})^\text{t}}\\[15pt]
&=\frac{\$1000}{(1+0.15)^{9}}\\[15pt]
&= \$284
\end{aligned}$$

Total bond value is therefore $334+  $284 = $618, which is as we expected, is lower.

This is important because par value ($1,000 in this case) HAS TO be paid at the end of maturity. Even if looked at original values from year 9, they would still adjust to $1,000 original dollars and selling price and par value would match up nicely.

However, with higher interest rate, seller is required to sell the bond at the lower price of $618, so when the buyer pays obligated $1,000, there is now already pregained at $382 for the buyer at maturity (ie. the seller got their $1,000 and the buyer has a gain for buying the bond at the lower price).
